nodes.bodyText: "all cancelled" is not handled
it does fall through to the second looping, but yeah I should check length == cancelledCount early in that loop too

should we even check for cancelled? I assume it would get removed, and we will only get a cancelled instance due to a race, but that's okay to still push things to a cancelled subscription since cancel() is not guaranteed to be instantly delivered
it is easy enough to check for it and I think it makes sense to unnecessarily avoid pushing elements when we know the downstream is cancelled
updated

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            			case FAIL_NON_SERIALIZED:
          
          
            
            			default:

I have a slight preference for not using default and having full explicit enum coverage, that way if we add an enum value the IDE can be configured to warn us. at least in tryEmitNext, which is the most likely to make use of most enums.

(Marked as not resolved, since... it is not resolved yet ;))
Unless we make our build fail when we forget to handle a new case, I'd say relying on IDE isn't a good idea. Also, not every team member/contributor has this option configured (I don't)
I initially thought the compiler would complain too, but it doesn't. ok let's make it a default block
updated
can't we reuse at least the inner class between this Sink and the existing processor?

not really, since the DirectInner terminates its downstream on backpressure. (also it would imply a common interface for DirectProcessor and SinkManyBestEffort for the inners to access parent.remove method)

But is this common interface a big deal?
The termination behaviour can be changed with two methods - emitXxx and tryEmitXxx, so that BestEffort will call "tryEmitXxx", while DirectProcessor would stick to emitXxx that calls tryEmitXxx and terminates
I've opened draft PR #2393 because I'm still not convinced this is in that much of a better state after trying your suggestion

I'd suggest to not use onBackpressureXxx at all since it is misleading anyways (we only return an Emission and not actually perform anything on backpressure)
Maybe Sinks.many().multicast().toAnyRequested() and Sinks.many().multicast().allOrNothing() or something similar?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -355,6 +355,48 @@ public Emission getReason() { * @param autoCancel should the sink fully shutdowns (not publishing anymore) when the last subscriber cancels */ Sinks.Many onBackpressureBuffer(int bufferSize, boolean autoCancel); + + /** + A {@link Sinks.Many} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: fail fast on {@link Many#tryEmitNext(Object) tryEmitNext}.
    • + *
  • Backpressure : notify the caller with {@link Emission#FAIL_OVERFLOW} if any of the subscribers + * cannot process an element, failing fast and backing off from emitting the element at all. + * From the perspective of subscribers, data is dropped and never seen but they are not terminated. + *
    • + *
  • Replaying: No replay of elements. Only forwards to a {@link Subscriber} the elements that + * have been pushed to the sink AFTER this subscriber was subscribed, provided all of the subscribers + * have demand.
    • + *
+ *

+ * + * @param the type of elements to emit + * @return a multicast {@link Sinks.Many} that "drops" in case any subscriber is too slow + */ + //TODO marble + Sinks.Many onBackpressureDropForAll();

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -355,6 +355,48 @@ public Emission getReason() { * @param autoCancel should the sink fully shutdowns (not publishing anymore) when the last subscriber cancels */ Sinks.Many onBackpressureBuffer(int bufferSize, boolean autoCancel); + + /** + A {@link Sinks.Many} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: fail fast on {@link Many#tryEmitNext(Object) tryEmitNext}.
    • + *
  • Backpressure : notify the caller with {@link Emission#FAIL_OVERFLOW} if any of the subscribers + * cannot process an element, failing fast and backing off from emitting the element at all (all or nothing). + * From the perspective of subscribers, data is dropped and never seen but they are not terminated. + *
    • + *
  • Replaying: No replay of elements. Only forwards to a {@link Subscriber} the elements that + * have been pushed to the sink AFTER this subscriber was subscribed, provided all of the subscribers + * have demand.
    • + *
+ *

+ * + * + * @param the type of elements to emit + * @return a multicast {@link Sinks.Many} that "drops" in case any subscriber is too slow + */ + Sinks.Many directAllOrNothing(); + + /** + A {@link Sinks.Many} with the following characteristics: + *

    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: fail fast on {@link Many#tryEmitNext(Object) tryEmitNext}.
    • + *
  • Backpressure : notify the caller with {@link Emission#FAIL_OVERFLOW} if none + * of the subscribers can process an element. Otherwise, it ignores slow subscribers and emits the + * element to fast ones as a best effort. From the perspective of slow subscribers, data is dropped + * and never seen, but they are not terminated. + *
    • + *
  • Replaying: No replay of elements. Only forwards to a {@link Subscriber} the elements that + * have been pushed to the sink AFTER this subscriber was subscribed.
    • + *
+ *

+ * + * + * @param the type of elements to emit + * @return a multicast {@link Sinks.Many} that "drops" in case any subscriber is too slow

nodes.bodyText:
I get a feeling that we will never start using JCstress if we will keep adding these for-based ones :(
this is a new code, goes into master where JCstress is configured, and I see no reason not to use it.
I have no idea what I'm doing, but done
this test does not seem to assert anything
fixed
resolved ?
if there is no shared code than the abstract class can be avoided (it is not required by JCstress or anything like that)
the abstract keyword you mean? I still need inner classes for individual tests I guess ?
you can as well have N classes/files, unless you want to group them, of course
yeah, I want to group the stress tests here
a stress test with a single actor does not make any sense
will remove
the whole point of JCstress is to run actors in parallel, so it won't always be "before", but before, at the same time and after the subscription
will rename
these two can be field initializers
done
fixed along added javadoc
shouldn't the request be strictly positive? I see some new StressSubscriber(0) usages in the tests
0 == no initial request
(added javadoc)
but there is no if (initRequest > 0) check before requesting
ah, sorry. good catch indeed
